properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy mix of wintry precipitation including a prolonged period of freezing rain. Precipitation is likely to begin as showers Wednesday afternoon across the area. However, as temperatures rapidly fall Wednesday evening, the showers are expected to quickly transition to a period of freezing rain. The freezing rain will likely continue for a few hours before transitioning to ice pellets and then snow by Thursday morning. A few hours of light snow will be possible by the time the precipitation comes to an end Thursday afternoon. Given the possibility of an extended period of freezing rain, appreciable ice accretions are likely and some power outages may occur. Residents are advised to monitor future forecasts closely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-10T13:23:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-03-09T21:24:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3799063689.2021
Area: White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow possible Wednesday night into Thursday. Snow is forecast to begin early Wednesday night and then become heavy late Wednesday night into Thursday. A general 10 to 15 cm of new snowfall can be expected, with the heaviest snowfall amounts likely away from the shores of Lake Superior. Some brief mixing with ice pellets will be possible particularly for areas near Lake Superior Wednesday night. Winter travel conditions can be expected and motorists are advised to check the latest forecasts as they become available. A Snowfall warning maybe required for portions of the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-10T13:15:28-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain is expected. What: Rain. Total accumulations of 15 to 25 mm are expected. Where: Parts of northeastern Ontario including Chapleau, Gogama, and Kirkland Lake. When: Wednesday morning into Thursday morning. Discussion: Rain will begin late Wednesday morning and likely last through much of the day. A break in the rain may occur Wednesday evening before an additional round overnight. Rainfall accumulations of 15 to 25 mm are anticipated. The ground has a reduced ability to absorb this rainfall due to being frozen and snow covered. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T02:41:15-00:00

Area: Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake, Gogama - Foleyet, Kirkland Lake - Englehart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy mix of wintry precipitation including a possible period of freezing rain. Precipitation is forecast to begin as showers Wednesday morning across the area. However, by Wednesday afternoon sharply falling temperatures will allow a wintry mix of precipitation to develop. Snow and ice pellets are likely, followed by a period of freezing rain Wednesday evening into Wednesday night. At this point in time, combined snow and ice pellet amounts of 10 cm appear possible, as well as light accretions of freezing rain. Precipitation is forecast to come to an end from west to east on Thursday. Given the expected messy mix of wintry precipitation, travel will be impacted across the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T02:39:44-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues through this afternoon. A low pressure system tracking northeastwards is bringing snow, heavy at times, across far northern Ontario. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 30 cm are expected. The snow will taper off from west to east this afternoon. Strong northeast winds gusting to 50 km/h at times will lead to periods of reduced visibility in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR SMITHERS AND BURNS LAKE (March 09, 2021 08:00 - Smithers) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Smithers and Burns Lake because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medical conditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-03-10T18:15:27-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. What: Heavy snow. Total accumulations of 10 to 20 cm are expected. Where: On a line approximately from Quetico Provincial Park to Pledger Lake, including Geraldton. This includes sections of Highway 11 and Highway 17. When: Wednesday evening through Thursday morning. Discussion: Periods of heavy snow are expected tonight, with rapid snowfall accumulation and poor visibility associated. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. DUST ADVISORY IN EFFECT FOR PRINCE GEORGE (March 09, 2021 08:00 AM - Prince George) The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with the Northern Health Authority has issued a Dust Advisory for Prince George because of high concentrations of coarse particulate matter that are expected to persist until there is precipitation, dust suppression or a change in traffic patterns. Levels tend to be highest around busy roads and industrial operations. This advisory is in effect until further notice. Exposure is particularly a concern for individuals with chronic conditions such as asthma, COPD, heart disease, and diabetes, respiratory infections such as COVID-19, pregnant women, infants, and older adults. Persons with chronic underlying medicalc onditions or acute infections should postpone or reduce strenuous exercise until the advisory is lifted. Where appropriate, maintain physical distancing. Anyone experiencing symptoms such as continuing eye or throat irritation, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, cough or wheezing, should follow the advice of their health care provider. Staying indoors helps to reduce particulate matter exposure. The City of Prince Georgeâ€™s Clean Air Bylaw prohibits all open burning, including backyard burning, and land clearing burning. During air quality advisories, this bylaw also prohibits recreational fires, use of wood-burning appliances (except for sole wood burning heat users), and street sweeping activities (unless approved by an Authorized Person). Industry is required to follow permit requirements that are triggered during air quality advisories and are asked to reduce emissions wherever possible. Real-time air quality observations and information regarding the health effects of air pollution can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain Wednesday night. What: Freezing rain. Ice accretion of 3 to 7 mm is expected. Where: Primarily a corridor along and north of Highway 101, including Timmins. This includes sections of Highway 17 and Highway 11. When: Wednesday evening into early Thursday morning. Discussion: Freezing rain is expected to develop as the temperature drops below the freezing mark on Wednesday night. Preceded with rain on Wednesday afternoon, the freezing rain will likely mix with ice pellets and snow overnight into Thursday morning. Ice accretion of 3 to 7 mm is expected. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-11T02:41:39-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Messy winter mix of precipitation tonight. A low pressure system tracking across Far Northern Ontario is bringing a large area of precipitation with it. Snow or a wet snow and rain mix is expected tonight. Brief periods of freezing rain are also possible. Untreated surfaces may become slippery from freezing rain and snow, resulting in difficult travel conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
